articles.headline: Angry Town Hall Meetings on Health Care Law, and Few Answers
articles.snippet: Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin and other Republicans are facing constituents demanding to know what will replace the Affordable Care Act — and so far, they have little to say.
articles.abstract: Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin and other Republicans are facing constituents demanding to know what will replace the Affordable Care Act — and so far, they have little to say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEWAUKEE, Wis. — Michelle Roelandts had a question for her congressman: If the Affordable Care Act and its premium subsidies were repealed, what would happen when her daughter turns 26 this year and needs to get her own health insurance while attending law school?

articles.headline: In Shadow of California Dam, Water Turns From Wish to Woe
articles.snippet: The sudden chaos unleashed by damage to a dam’s spillway offered a dramatic reversal for Northern California, which until recently was parched by drought.
articles.abstract: The sudden chaos unleashed by damage to a dam’s spillway offered a dramatic reversal for Northern California, which until recently was parched by drought.
articles.lead_paragraph: OROVILLE, Calif. — It wasn’t so long ago that residents here had to drag their houseboats into a dusty field from the barren banks of Lake Oroville, which had almost no water left to keep them afloat.
articles.byline: By Mike McPhate and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: From Trump’s Mar-a-Lago to Facebook, a National Security Crisis in the Open
articles.snippet: President Trump and his aides coordinated their response to North Korea’s missile test at his Florida club without retiring to a secure location.
articles.abstract: President Trump and his aides coordinated their response to North Korea’s missile test at his Florida club without retiring to a secure location.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his top aides coordinated their response to North Korea’s missile test on Saturday night in full view of diners at Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida — a remarkable public display of presidential activity that is almost always conducted in highly secure settings.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Banks Look to Cellphones to Replace A.T.M. Cards
articles.snippet: Major banks are unveiling teller machines across the country that customers can gain access to with their phones. But the technology raises new security issues.
articles.abstract: Major banks are unveiling teller machines across the country that customers can gain access to with their phones. But the technology raises new security issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wallets can be lost, stolen or forgotten, but most people today wouldn’t be caught dead without their phones.

articles.headline: Michael Flynn Resigns as National Security Adviser
articles.snippet: Mr. Flynn, who served in the job for less than a month, said he had given “incomplete information” about a telephone call with the Russian ambassador before President Trump’s inauguration.
articles.abstract: Mr. Flynn, who served in the job for less than a month, said he had given “incomplete information” about a telephone call with the Russian ambassador before President Trump’s inauguration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser, resigned on Monday night after it was revealed that he had misled Vice President Mike Pence and other top White House officials about his conversations with the Russian ambassador to the United States.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Matthew Rosenberg, Matt Apuzzo and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Union Vote at Boeing Plant Tests Labor’s Sway Under Trump
articles.snippet: A bid to organize workers in South Carolina challenges the company’s leverage over the union at its facilities near Seattle.
articles.abstract: A bid to organize workers in South Carolina challenges the company’s leverage over the union at its facilities near Seattle.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Boeing came to South Carolina more than seven years ago to establish a second assembly line for its 787 Dreamliner aircraft. At least part of the attraction, analysts said, was the area’s lightly unionized labor force — giving the company more leverage over the union at its main operations outside Seattle.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: A Billionaire’s Party Is a Lens on Wealth in the Trump Era
articles.snippet: Ten years ago, the financier Stephen A. Schwarzman was vilified for his lavish 60th bash; this year, in the Trump era, things seem to have changed.
articles.abstract: Ten years ago, the financier Stephen A. Schwarzman was vilified for his lavish 60th bash; this year, in the Trump era, things seem to have changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: So, Stephen A. Schwarzman had another birthday party.

articles.headline: Case of Captive in Yemen Could Test Trump’s Guantánamo Pledge
articles.snippet: A terrorism suspect could present a legal and policy experiment for Mr. Trump, who has promised to resume sending suspects to the military prison.
articles.abstract: A terrorism suspect could present a legal and policy experiment for Mr. Trump, who has promised to resume sending suspects to the military prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering what to do about a Qaeda suspect being held in Yemen, a decision that presents an early test of President Trump’s campaign pledge to send terrorism suspects to the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Matt Apuzzo and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: An Afghan Mother’s Heartache: Three Sons Dead in a Day
articles.snippet: A 15-year war that both sides have said cannot be won on the battlefield is claiming more lives than ever, most of them Afghan security forces.
articles.abstract: A 15-year war that both sides have said cannot be won on the battlefield is claiming more lives than ever, most of them Afghan security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For years, Shaima has toiled to make a home for her family in a congested district of Kabul, down a narrow alley in the shadow of a mountain.

articles.headline: Trump’s Shift to ‘Outside-In’ Strategy for Mideast Peace Is a Long Shot
articles.snippet: A regional approach relying on Arab states has been tried before, and many Palestinians and Israelis are skeptical.
articles.abstract: A regional approach relying on Arab states has been tried before, and many Palestinians and Israelis are skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMAD CITY, Gaza Strip — Wail al-Gatshan is grateful for his new apartment here in a growing neighborhood in southern Gaza. For just $140 a month, there are separate bedrooms for his three girls and two boys, as well as a guest bathroom.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Can Immigration Hurt the Economy? An Old Prejudice Returns
articles.snippet: An unsettling assertion that immigrants can erode social norms and productivity has a foothold in academic circles.
articles.abstract: An unsettling assertion that immigrants can erode social norms and productivity has a foothold in academic circles.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a nation of immigrants, the United States has worked hard to keep foreigners out.
